questions.text: Which of the following thiazide diuretics is appropriate for a 34-year-old man with hypertension and stage 4 chronic kidney disease, characterized by an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) below 30?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - M

questions.text: A patient with a history of hypertension is given the drug ‘X’. Identify ‘X’?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Alisk

questions.text: Which drug elicits the following response on blood pressure and heart rate, as shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Norepinephrine

Description

Norepinephrine, or noradrenaline, is a sympathomimetic drug used primarily as a vasopressor.

Mechanism of Action (MOA)

It acts on α1 and β1 adrenergic receptors and has some affinity for alpha-2 receptors.

  • Activation of α1 receptors causes vasoconstriction, increasing peripheral resistance and blood pressure.
  • Activation of β1 receptors increases heart rate and myocardial contractility.

Uses
  • Treatment of acute hypotension (e.g., septic shock, cardiogenic shock).
  • Cardiac arrest.

Side effects
  • Cardiovascular: Arrhythmias, bradycardia, hypertension.
  • CNS: Anxiety, headache, tremor.
  • Gastrointestinal: Nausea, vomiting.
  • Respiratory: Respiratory difficulty, dyspnea.
  • Metabolic: Hyperglycemia, lactic acidosis.

Contraindications
  • Peripheral vascular thrombosis (risk of ischemia).
  • During anesthesia with cyclopropane or halothane (due to the risk of arrhythmias).
  • Hypotension is due to blood volume deficits (hypovolemia) until an adequate fluid replacement.

questions.text: Which of the following is the false statement regarding statins?

options.label: A
options.text: Although HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors substantially reduce the risk of cardiovascular events, there is a mild increase in lipoprotein a (Lpa) levels.

options.label: B
options.text: These drugs should not be stopped even in severe conditions like injury, surgery etc.

options.label: C
options.text: They can be given with verapamil and other enzyme inhibitors

options.label: D
options.text: With long-term use, there is a slight increase in the incidence of type 2 diabetes mellitus.

questions.correct_answer: C. They can be given with verapamil and other enzyme inhibitors
questions.explanation:
Drugs

Mechanism of action

Statins / HMG CoA reductase inhibitors

  • Atorvastatin
  • Rosuvastatin
  • Simvastatin
  • Pitavastatin
  • Pravastatin

Inhibits HMG CoA reductase ➜ ￬cholesterol production in the liver (￬LDL cholesterol)

Fibrates / Activates PPAR-α

  • Gemfibrozil
  • Bezafibrate
  • Fenofibrate

Activates PPAR-α ➜ ￪expression of genes involved responsible for triglycerides breakdown and VLDL clearance.

Fibrates can ￬triglycerides and ￪HDL cholesterol levels.

Resins / Bile acid sequestrants

  • Cholestyramine
  • Colesevelam
  • Colestipol

Sequestrates bile acids (￬recycling of bile acids from the intestine to the liver) ➜ To compensate for this, the liver increases the conversion of cholesterol into bile acid ➜ ￬in hepatic cholesterol levels.

Lipolysis inhibitor/Triglyceride synthesis inhibitor

  • Niacin (Nicotinic acid)

Inhibits lipolysis in adipose tissue ➜ ￬hepatic synthesis of VLDL and LDL ➜ ￬LDL cholesterol and triglycerides in blood.

Niacin also inhibits the breakdown of HDL ➜ ￪HDL levels.

Ezetimibe
  • Disrupts cholesterol and phytosterol absorption in small intestines via PCIL1 transporter protein interference.
  • Ezetimibe, with statins, enhances LDL-C reduction by inhibiting the rise of statin-induced cholesterol synthesis.

questions.text: Identify the correct match, regarding the drug and its adverse effect.:
questions.explanation:
Verapamil

Class of Drug

Phenylalkylamine class of CCB

MOA

Blocks the influx of calcium ions into smooth muscle cells, which reduces the force of contraction and dilates the blood vessels.

Effects

It primarily affects cardiac muscle, leading to negative inotropic effects and slow conduction through the AV node.

Absorption

Rapid from the gastrointestinal tract; peak plasma concentrations in 1- 2 hours.

Elimination

Extensively metabolized in the liver, excreted in urine.

Common side effects

Constipation, dizziness, headache, hypotension.

questions.text: An anti–arrhythmic drug is shown to have the following effect. It is effective in both atrial and ventricular arrhythmias. Identify the drug.

Match the following antiarrhythmic drugs with their mechanism of action: Mechanism of action Drug Na + channel blocker K + channel blocker Na + , K + ATPase inhibitor Beta-blocker Quinidine Digoxin Esmolol Ibutilde
questions.explanation:
Drug

MOA

Quinidine

Is a Na+ channel blocker, which is a class I antiarrhythmic drug that acts by blocking sodium channels in the cardiac cells. By blocking these channels, it decreases the influx of sodium ions during the depolarization phase of the cardiac action potential.

Digoxin

It is a Na+ K+ ATPase inhibitor, which is not primarily considered an antiarrhythmic drug but rather a cardiac glycoside. However, it does have some antiarrhythmic effects. Digoxin inhibits the activity of the Na+ K+ ATPase pump, and increases intracellular calcium levels, leading to increased contractility of the heart. This indirectly helps to control certain arrhythmias, such as atrial fibrillation

Esmolol

It belongs to the class of beta-blockers, specifically a short-acting selective beta-1 adrenergic receptor blocker. It works by blocking the beta-1 adrenergic receptors in the heart, thereby reducing the effects of sympathetic stimulation.

Ibutilide

It is a potassium channel blocker, which is a class III antiarrhythmic drug that primarily blocks potassium channels in the heart. By inhibiting these channels, it prolongs the repolarization phase of the cardiac action potential, resulting in an increase in the action potential duration and effective refractory period.

Class of Drug

Mechanism of action

Sodium channel blockers (Class 1)

 

Class 1A

  • Quinidine
  • Procainamide
  • Disopyramide

Blocks sodium channels (Na+) during phase 0 of the cardiac action potential.
 

Class 1B

  • Lidocaine
  • Mexiletine

Blocks sodium channels (Na+) during phase 0 of the cardiac action potential, but with fast dissociation.
 

Class 1C

  • Flecainide
  • Propafenone

Potent sodium channel blockers (Na+) with slow dissociation from the channel.

Beta-blockers (Class 2)

  • Propranolol
  • Metoprolol
  • Esmolol
  • Carvedilol

Decrease SA and AV nodal activity by ↓ cAMP, thereby ↓ Ca currents.

Potassium channel blockers (Class 3)

  • Amiodarone
  • Ibutilide
  • Dofetilide
  • Sotalol

Delays repolarization, lengthens the cardiac action potential, and increases the refractory period.

Calcium channel blockers (Class 4)

  • Diltiazem
  • Verapamil

Reducing calcium influx during phase 2 of the cardiac action potential and decreases myocardial contractility, heart rate, and AV nodal conduction velocity.


 

Miscellaneous drugs (Class 5)

  • Atropine
  • Adenosine
  • Digoxin
  •  
  • Magnesium sulfate
  1. Atropine: DOC in bradyarrhythmias
  2. Adenosine: used in acute attacks of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia and to treat supra-ventricular tachycardia in heart failure patients
  3. Digoxin: Treat atrial flutter/fibrillation
  4. Magnesium sulfate: DOC in Torsades de pointes

questions.text: Which of the medications listed below is considered safe for the treatment of pregnancy-induced hypertension?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Alpha methyldopa

Antihypertensives in Pregnancy
  • DOC: Labetaolol (Beta-blocker)
  • If chronic hypertension develops, Alpha methyldopa
  • Safe antihypertensives during pregnancy
  • Labetalol, Hydralazine, Methyldopa, and Calcium channel blockers like Nifedipine. (LHMC- Lady Hardinge Medical College)

Unsafe antihypertensive drugs during pregnancy:

  • ACE inhibitors (Option A) & ARBs (Option D): Can lead to renal agenesis in the fetus, causing oligohydramnios and leading to POTTER sequence (Pulmonary hypoplasia, Oligohydramnios, Twisted/wrinkled skin, Twisted Potter faces, Extremity defects, Renal agenesis).
  • Thiazides/Loop diuretics/Beta-blockers (Option B): Bear the risk of placental ischemia, which can be fatal to the fetus.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with a chronic dry cough with no fever or other associated symptoms. He had recently been started on an antihypertensive for hypertension. Which among the following is most likely responsible for causing these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Only bradykinin

Adverse Effect

Description

Hypotension

Decrease in blood pressure, especially upon initiation of therapy or with dosage increases.

Hyperkalemia

Increased serum potassium levels due to reduced aldosterone secretion.

Cough

Persistent dry cough, possibly due to bradykinin buildup in the lungs.

Angioedema

Due to increased bradykinin levels, swelling of deeper layers of skin, particularly around the eyes and lips, can be life-threatening.

Rashes/Urticaria

Skin reactions like rashes or hives occur in a small percentage of users.

Dysgeusia

Reversible taste changes are more common with captopril.

Rare Effects

Granulocytopenia (low white blood cells) and proteinuria (excess protein in urine) are more concerning in patients with kidney disease.

Acute Renal Failure

Possible in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis due to decreased kidney filtration.

Fetal Effects

ACE inhibitors are contraindicated during pregnancy due to potential harm to the fetus, including fetal renal damage due to inhibition of the fetal renin-angiotensin system.

questions.text: In patients with indications for warfarin usage, what is the recommended range of INR in a patient with mechanical heart valves?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - 2.5-3.5

questions.text: What is the preferred medication for managing ventricular arrhythmia caused by digoxin?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Lig

questions.text: A 57-year-old man was brought to the hospital with complaints of dizziness and breathlessness. During the physical examination, his face appears to be discoloured. His current medication includes Amiodarone, Metoprolol, Verapamil, Lisinopril and Amlodipine. Which of the following drugs is responsible for these skin changes?
questions.explanation:
Amiodarone

MOA 
  • Prolonged action potential duration and QT interval by blocking delayed rectifier K+ channels.
  • Blocks inactivated Na+ channels, with rapid channel recovery (Decrease phase 0 slope).
  • Partially inhibits myocardial Ca2+ channels, adding to its antiarrhythmic effects.
  • Used to treat both atrial and ventricular fibrillation

Uses

To maintain normal sinus rhythm during atrial fibrillation and prevent recurrent ventricular tachycardia.

Adverse effects
  • Hypotension and Bradycardia (with i.v administration or after drug accumulation)
  • Photosensitivity: Skin pigmentation - Purple colour (purple man syndrome, smurf syndrome)
  • Corneal microdeposits: Reversible upon drug discontinuation.
  • Pulmonary alveolitis and fibrosis (On long-term use)
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Thyroid Dysfunction: Interfere with thyroid function as it acts as a source of iodine and can potentially lead to goitre, hypothyroidism (Wolf Chaikoff effect), or, in rare cases, hyperthyroidism (Jos-Basedow effect).

Interactions
  • Inhibits CYP3A4, CYP2C9, and P-glycoprotein, leading to potential interactions with drugs metabolized by this system.
  • Increases plasma levels of digoxin and warfarin.
  • Additive AV block with beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers.

questions.text: What is the half-life of digoxin?
Inhaled Nitric oxide is approved for the treatment of?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Pulmonary hypertension

Nitric Oxide

Inhaled nitric oxide is a gas that is used to treat pulmonary hypertension because it acts as a potent vasodilator, meaning it relaxes the smooth muscle in the walls of the pulmonary arteries and improves blood flow.

MOA

Activation of guanylate cyclase, which converts guanosine triphosphate (GTP) to cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP)

cGMP causes relaxation of the smooth muscle cells in the pulmonary arteries, leading to vasodilation of the vessels

Uses

Therapeutic indication

  • Pulmonary arterial hypertension
  • Rescue therapy for severely hypoxemic patients

 

Diagnostic indication

  • To evaluate pulmonary reactivity during cardiac catheterisation.
  • To determine diffusion capacity across the alveolar-capillary unit.

Adverse effects

  • Headache, nausea and vomiting
  • Methemoglobinemia
  • It may worsen left ventricular performance in those with impaired ventricular function.

Drugs for Pulmonary artery hypertension

Mechanism of action

Drugs

PDE 5 Inhibitors

Sildenafil (Viagra), Tadalafil

Endothelin Receptor Antagonists

Bosentan, Sitaxsentan, Ambrisentan

PG-I2 Analogs

Treprostinil, Iloprost, Epoprostenol

Soluble Guanylyl Cyclase Activators

Riociguat

I-2 prostaglandin agonist

Selexipag

Continuous NO Inhalation

Nitric oxide

Calcium Channel Blockers

Amlodipine, Nifedipine

questions.text: A 35-year-old chronic hypertensive woman comes to the OPD for preconception counselling. Which of the following antihypertensives should be discontinued in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Antihypertensives in pregnancy

To be used

To be avoided

  • Labetalol (α + β receptor antagonist)
  • Nifedipine (Calcium channel blocker *)
  • α - Methyldopa
  • Hydralazine
  • Thiazides can be used in chronic hypertension in pregnant women
  • ACEi and ARB - teratogenic
  • Diuretic - reduces uteroplacental perfusion
  • Non-selective beta-blocker

* CCB can be useful in preeclampsia, but they must be stopped before labour as they can weaken uterine contractions

questions.text: A patient who was recently started on an antihypertensive presented with the following presentation, as shown in the image below. Which of the following antihypertensive medications was most likely prescribed to him?
questions.explanation:
Adverse effects of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors

Hypotension

Decrease in blood pressure, especially upon initiation of therapy or with dosage increases.

Hyperkalemia

Increased serum potassium levels due to reduced aldosterone secretion.

Cough

Persistent dry cough, possibly due to bradykinin buildup in the lungs.

Angioedema

Due to increased bradykinin levels, swelling of deeper layers of skin, particularly around the eyes and lips, can be life-threatening.

Rashes/Urticaria

Skin reactions like rashes or hives occur in a small percentage of users.

Dysgeusia

Reversible taste changes are more common with captopril.

Rare Effects

Granulocytopenia (low white blood cells) and proteinuria (excess protein in urine) are more concerning in patients with kidney disease.

Acute Renal Failure

Possible in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis due to decreased kidney filtration.

Fetal Effects

ACE inhibitors are contraindicated during pregnancy due to potential harm to the fetus, including fetal renal damage due to inhibition of the fetal renin-angiotensin system.

questions.text: Which anti-hypertensive medication is suitable for administration to a patient suffering from renal insufficiency, exhibiting symptoms of significantly reduced urine output, pedal edema, headache, and a blood pressure reading of 160/90?
questions.explanation:
Drug

Use

Rationale for Choice

Nifedipine

(Short-acting)

Primarily used for angina pectoris.

It is not recommended for long-term hypertension management due to its short duration of action and potential for reflex tachycardia.

Nicardipine

(Short-acting)

It is commonly used in the management of hypertensive emergencies and perioperative hypertension or severe hypertension in the intensive care unit.

The short duration of action makes it less suitable for long-term hypertension management.

Clevidipine

(Ultra-short-acting)

Very short half-life makes it unsuitable for long-term hypertension management.

Amlodipine

(Long-acting)

Recommended as a first-line or add-on therapy for the long-term management of hypertension.

Preferred choice due to its long duration of action (up to 24 hours), once-daily dosing, and effectiveness in lowering blood pressure with good tolerability.

questions.text: Which of the following side effects are likely to be observed when a patient already taking metoprolol is prescribed verapamil? a) Bradycardia with Av Block b) Torsades De Pointes c) Tachycardia d) Ventricular Fibrillation
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts by inhibiting the late sodium current in the heart?
questions.explanation:
Ranolazine

MOA
  • Inhibits the late sodium current in cardiomyocytes, which helps to reduce intracellular sodium accumulation during ischemic conditions
  • Indirectly reduces calcium overload in cardiac cells and improves myocardial relaxation, leading to an anti-ischemic effect.
  • It decreases ventricular diastolic tension, reduces myocardial oxygen consumption, and improves myocardial perfusion

Uses

  • Used as add-on therapy as an Antianginal agent for Chronic stable angina.
  • Reduces the frequency of angina pectoris and improves exercise tolerance.
  • Ventricular tachycardia.
  • Improves glycemic control (lower HbA1c and increase insulin)

Adverse effect

  • Dizziness, headache, nausea and asthenia
  • Constipation and Liver failure
  • QT-prolongation and rarely Ventricular arrhythmia such as Torsades de pointes.

questions.text: Which of the following antiarrhythmic drugs is contraindicated in a patient with interstitial lung disease?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Amiodarone

Drugs

Lung disorders

Amniodarone

 

 

Pulmonary fibrosis

Bleomycin

Busulfan

Nitrofurantoin

Rarely associated with chronic pulmonary fibrosis

Cyclophosphamide

 

Interstitial pneumonitis, which can lead to pulmonary fibrosis

Methotrexate

questions.text: A person presents with acute chest pain. Nitro-glycerine was given sublingually, and pain relief occurred within a minute. What is the mechanism of this drug?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Release of nitric oxide

Nitrates

Drugs

  • Glyceryl trinitrate
  • Isosorbide dinitrate
  • Isosorbide mononitrate
  • Pentaerythritol tetranitrate

MOA
  • Venodilation → Reduce preload → Reduce myocardial contractility → Decreased O2 demand.
  • Dilates coronary artery (increase cGMP): effective in vasospastic angina.
  • Redistribution of coronary blood flow to the ischemic area (Robinhood phenomenon).

Uses
  • Angina (stable, vasospastic and chronic)
  • Acute coronary syndrome or myocardial infarction (STEMI/NSTEMI)
  • Acute pulmonary edema
  • Abdominal colicky pain

questions.text: A patient has pain in the facial nerve distribution while chewing and speaking. Which of the following drugs should be given for the treatment?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Carbamazepine

Drugs for trigeminal neuralgia

Drug

Mechanism of Action

Uses

Side Effects

Carbamazepine

Inhibits high-frequency neuronal discharges and modulates voltage-gated sodium channels.

Trigeminal neuralgia

GTCS, partial seizures, bipolar disorder.

Sedation, dizziness, ataxia, GI disturbances, bone marrow suppression, hypersensitivity reactions, water retention.

Gabapentin

Enhances GABA release modulates voltage-sensitive Ca2+ channels.

Partial seizures, post-herpetic neuralgia, migraine prophylaxis.

Sedation, tiredness, dizziness, tremor, unsteadiness.

Diazepam

Enhances GABAergic neurotransmission.

Status epilepticus,

Febrile seizure.

Thrombophlebitis, hypotension, respiratory depression.

Topiramate

Multiple mechanisms, including sodium channel inactivation, GABA potentiation, glutamate receptor antagonism, and potassium channel modulation.

GTCS, myoclonic epilepsy, and absence of seizures.

Impairment of attention, sedation, ataxia, word-finding difficulties, poor memory, weight loss, paresthesias, renal stones.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent antihypertensive medications are contraindicated during pregnancy?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C: P

questions.text: Which of these drugs stimulates PPAR-alpha?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Gemfibrozil

Class

Fibrate or PPAR-α agonist

Mechanism of action

Activate peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPAR-α), leading to the following effects:

  • Reduce triglyceride production
  • Elevate high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol levels
  • Decrease hepatic triglyceride synthesis

Uses

Hyperlipidemia

Adverse effects

  • GI side effects (nausea, abdominal pain, diarrhea)
  • Myopathy, especially when used with statins
  • Hepatotoxicity (elevated liver enzymes)
  • Renal dysfunction
  • Gallbladder disease
  • Contraindicated in children and pregnancy

questions.text: A patient who has recently had a myocardial infarction (MI) presents for a follow-up. His cholesterol levels are as follows: total cholesterol 238 mg/dL, triglycerides 125 mg/dL, and HDL 50 mg/dL. He is currently taking atorvastatin, metoprolol, and aspirin. Which of the following medications should be added to his regimen? Ezetimibe Bempedoic acid Evolocumab Gemfibrozil
Scientists administered norepinephrine to guinea pigs, resulting in an increase in systolic and diastolic blood pressure and a decrease in heart rate. What mechanism explains this response?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Mechanism
  • Baroreceptors in carotid sinus and aortic arch detect BP changes
  • Increased BP stretches receptors, sending signals to medulla via glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves
  • Medulla inhibits vasoconstrictor center and stimulates vagal parasympathetic center

Actions
  • Vasodilation of blood vessels
  • Decreased heart rate and contraction strength
  • Reduced BP due to lower peripheral resistance and cardiac output

Importance
  • Maintains BP stability during activities like standing
  • Fastest acting
  • Tends to reset within 1-2 days for long-term regulation

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis is taking indomethacin and an ACE inhibitor for hypertension. What potential side effect is likely to be seen?
questions.explanation:
Drug Interaction

Mechanism

Clinical Implication

ACE Inhibitors + Potassium Supplements/K-sparing diuretics

Risk of hyperkalemia due to reduced aldosterone secretion by ACE inhibitors combined with potassium-retaining agents.

Monitoring serum potassium levels is crucial to avoid hyperkalemia, which can cause serious cardiac issues such as arrhythmias.

ACE Inhibitors + NSAIDs

NSAIDs can reduce the anti-hypertensive effects of ACE inhibitors and decrease renal blood flow, increasing the risk of acute renal failure (ARF) or oliguria.

Use caution when combining NSAIDs with ACE inhibitors, and closely monitor renal function, particularly in high-risk patients.

ACE Inhibitors + Lithium

ACE inhibitors can increase the reabsorption of lithium, potentially leading to lithium toxicity.

Monitor lithium levels carefully when starting or adjusting ACE inhibitors in patients taking lithium, and adjust the lithium dosage as needed.

ACE Inhibitors + Antacids

Reduced bioavailability of ACE inhibitors due to binding with antacids.

Administer ACE inhibitors at least two hours before or after antacids to maintain their efficacy.

ACE Inhibitors + Diuretics

Diuretics enhance the hypotensive effects of ACE inhibitors by depleting sodium and raising renin levels.

In patients already on diuretics, start ACE inhibitors at a low dose to minimise the risk of excessive blood pressure reduction initially.

questions.text: Which antihypertensive drug is contraindicated in pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Adverse Effect

Description

Hypotension

Decrease in blood pressure, especially upon initiation of therapy or with dosage increases.

Hyperkalemia

Increased serum potassium levels due to reduced aldosterone secretion.

Cough

Persistent dry cough, possibly due to bradykinin buildup in the lungs.

Angioedema

Due to increased bradykinin levels, swelling of deeper layers of skin, particularly around the eyes and lips, can be life-threatening.

Rashes/Urticaria

Skin reactions like rashes or hives occur in a small percentage of users.

Dysgeusia

Reversible taste changes are more common with captopril.

Rare Effects

Granulocytopenia (low white blood cells) and proteinuria (excess protein in urine) are more concerning in patients with kidney disease.

Acute Renal Failure

Possible in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis due to decreased kidney filtration.

Fetal Effects

ACE inhibitors are contraindicated during pregnancy due to potential harm to the fetus, including fetal renal damage due to inhibition of the fetal renin-angiotensin system.

questions.text: Which of the following beta-adrenergic blockers used in the treatment of chronic heart failure (CHF) is known to prolong survival?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - B

questions.text: Which anticoagulant is recommended for a pregnant female at 29 weeks of gestation who develops deep vein thrombosis (DVT) with calf tenderness and is diagnosed via Doppler ultrasound?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH)

questions.text: A hypertensive patient is suffering from frequent attacks of renal colic. Preferred anti hypertensive drug is:
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Hydrochloroth

questions.text: A hypertensive patient stopped antihypertensive medication due to dry eyes, dry mouth and constipation. After stopping the drug, he developed hypertensive emergency (BP > 180/120). Most likely drug is:
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - C

questions.text: A patient with raised triglyceride started on medication. He soon developed flushing, gout and raised liver enzymes. Likely cause is:
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Nicotinamide (Niacin)

questions.text: An unconscious patient found to have hot dry skin, dilated pupils, abnormal slurred speech. Most likely overdose is?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Dhatu

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects is least likely to be associated with the use of amiodarone?
questions.explanation:
Amiodarone

MOA
  • It prolongs action potential duration and QT interval by blocking delayed rectifier K+ channels.
  • Blocks inactivated Na+ channels, with rapid channel recovery (Decrease phase 0 slope).
  • It partially inhibits myocardial Ca2+ channels, adding to its antiarrhythmic effects.
  • It is used to treat both atrial and ventricular fibrillation.

Drug interactions
  • Inhibits CYP3A4, CYP2C9, and P-glycoprotein, leading to potential interactions with drugs metabolized by this system.
  • Increases plasma levels of digoxin and warfarin.
  • Additive AV block with beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers.

Adverse reactions
  • Hypotension and Bradycardia (with i.v administration or after drug accumulation)
  • Photosensitivity: Skin pigmentation - Purple colour (purple man syndrome, smurf syndrome)
  • Corneal microdeposits: Reversible upon drug discontinuation.
  • Pulmonary alveolitis and fibrosis, on long-term use (Option D ruled out)
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Thyroid Dysfunction: Interfere with thyroid function as it acts as a source of iodine and can potentially lead to goitre, hypothyroidism (Wolf Chaikoff effect), or, in rare cases, hyperthyroidism (Jos-Basedow effect). (Option A and B ruled out)

questions.text: Identify the Pcsk9 inhibitor.
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Evolocu

questions.text: Which of the following drugs reduces mortality in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFREF)?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Metoprolol

Cardiac side effects

Extracardiac side effects
  • Withdrawal can lead to the precipitation of an acute MI.
  • Negative chronotropic effects include the development of sinus bradycardia and heart block.
  • Heart failure may exacerbate symptoms in patients with decompensated heart failure or preexisting myocardial dysfunction.

 
  • Increased airway resistance (contraindicated in patients with asthma due to bronchospasm).
  • Exacerbation of peripheral artery disease and worsen claudication and precipitate Raynaud's disease.
  • Masking of the hypoglycemic signs (tachycardia).
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Depression, fatigue, and sexual dysfunction such as erectile dysfunction.
  • Weight gain

 

First generation(Older / non selective)

Second generation

(Cardioselective)

Third generation

  • Propranolol
  • Sotalol
  • Pindolol (100% bioavailability)
  • Timolol
  • Nadolol (Maximum t1/2)
  • Metoprolol
  • Esmolol (Minimum t1/2)
  • Atenolol
  • Bisoprolol
  • Acebutolol
  •  
  •  

With alpha-blocking activity

  • Labetalol
  • Celiprolol
  • Nebivolol
  • Betaxolol

With calcium channel blockade

  • Carvedilol (maximum plasma protein binding )

With beta 2 agonism

  • Bopindolol

With K+ channel opening action

  • Tilisolol

Without ISA

questions.text: Drug of choice for acute rheumatic fever?
questions.explanation:
Management of ARF

Treatment for

Medication used

Group streptococcal infection
  • Penicillin/Erythromycin/Azithromycin.
  • 10 days or oral Amoxicillin or a single dose of IM benzathine penicillin.
  • Azithromycin in case of Penicillin allergy.

Symptomatic management
  • Salicylates like aspirin (NSAIDs as an alternative option)
  • It is the first-line treatment for arthritis, fever, and inflammation. Dose: High initially, then taper as symptoms improve.

Carditis
  • Corticosteroids.
  • Diuretics like Furosemide are used if heart failure symptoms due to rheumatic carditis are present. (Option D ruled out)

Chorea
  • It is managed conservatively, or Valproic acid is used for the sedation

CCF

Diuretics and vasodilators are used.

Prophylaxis

(is essential to prevent recurrent infections and further damage to the heart)

Inj. Benzathine penicillin is given every 3-4 weeks IM

  • 6 lakh IU in children ≤27 kg.
  • 1.2 million IU in children >27 kg

Bed rest is advised

Major criteria

Minor criteria
  • Clinical or subclinical evidence of carditis (e.g., new murmur)
  • Migratory polyarthritis (Two or more joints involved)
  • Sydenham chorea (involuntary movements)
  • Erythema marginatum (characteristic skin rash)
  • Subcutaneous nodules
  • Previous rheumatic fever or rheumatic heart disease
  • Fever (≥38.5°C)
  • Poly or mono arthralgia
  • Elevated acute phase reactants (e.g., CRP, ESR)
  • Prolonged PR interval on ECG

The presence of two major criteria, or one major criterion + two minor criteria (along with evidence of preceding streptococcal infection), supports the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever (ARF) according to the Jones criteria.

questions.text: The true statement among the following is ___:

options.label: A
options.text: Telmisartan dose should be reduced in renal failure but not in hepatic failure.

options.label: B
options.text: Irbesartan dose should be reduced in case of mild-moderate hepatic failure and renal failure.

options.label: C
options.text: Candesartan dose should be reduced in mild-moderate liver failure but not in renal failure.

options.label: D
options.text: Losartan acts as a thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation.

questions.correct_answer: D. Losartan acts as a thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation.
questions.explanation:
Losartan

Indications

Hypertension, diabetic nephropathy

Mechanism of action

Angiotension II receptor antagonist

Adverse effects

Hypotension, hyperkalemia, renal impairment, dizziness, fatigue, cough, headache, upper respiratory tract infection

Contraindications

Hypersensitivity to losartan, pregnancy, breastfeeding

Drug interactions

Potassium supplements and other drugs that increase potassium levels, NSAIDs, diuretics, rifampin, ritonavir

Dosage form

Tablets (25mg, 50mg, 100mg)

Route of administration

Oral

Half-life

1.5-2 hours

Precautions

Use cautiously in renal and hepatic impairment, heart failure, and aortic stenosis.

questions.text: A patient with a previous MI and ventricular arrhythmia is on treatment for a few months. He developed fatigue, dyspnea and weight gain. He had also developed pulmonary fibrosis. Which of the following drugs is responsible for this?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Amiodarone

Mechanism of Action
  • Prolonged action potential duration and QT interval by blocking delayed rectifier K+ channels.
  • Blocks inactivated Na+ channels, with rapid channel recovery (Decrease phase 0 slope).
  • Partially inhibits myocardial Ca2+ channels, adding to its antiarrhythmic effects.

Adverse effects
  • Hypotension and Bradycardia (with i.v administration or after drug accumulation)
  • Photosensitivity: Skin pigmentation - Purple color (Purple man syndrome, smurf syndrome)
  • Corneal microdeposits: Reversible upon drug discontinuation.
  • Pulmonary alveolitis and fibrosis (On long-term use)
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Thyroid Dysfunction: Interfere with thyroid function as it acts as a source of iodine and can potentially lead to goitre, hypothyroidism (Wolf Chaikoff effect), or, in rare cases, hyperthyroidism (Jos-Basedow effect).

Drug Interactions
  • Inhibits CYP3A4, CYP2C9, and P-glycoprotein, leading to potential interactions with drugs metabolized by this system.
  • Increases plasma levels of digoxin and warfarin.
  • Additive AV block with beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers.

questions.text: Below is an image of angiotensin II synthesis and neprilysin action with two arrows at ACE and Neprilysin. Which drug acts on both enzymes?
questions.explanation:

Omapatrilat

Uses

Adverse Effects

A 32-year-old pregnant female presents to the emergency department with a BP of 220/120mm Hg, along with headache, seizure, and blurred vision. Which of the following is the preferred intravenous medication for the management of hypertension in pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Drug Class

Examples

Notes

Beta-blockers

Labetalol

Preferred. Generally safe and effective

Calcium channel blockers

Nifedipine

Amlodipine

Safe, less BP variability compared to labetalol

Drug Class

Examples

Notes

Vasodilators

Hydralazine

Reserved for cases with cardiac/renal dysfunction

Drug Class

Examples

Notes

ACE inhibitors

Enalapril, Lisinopril

Associated with severe fetal malformations

Angiotensin-receptor blockers

Losartan, Valsartan

Not recommended at any point during pregnancy

questions.text: Which of the following GPCRs does not act via the K + channel ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Angiotensin

Aspect

Description

Classification

Transmembrane receptors that transmit signals through G-proteins.

Activation Mechanism

Ligand binding (hormones, neurotransmitters, etc.) causes conformational changes in the receptor.

G-Protein Activation

Ligand-bound receptor activates G-protein by promoting exchange of GDP for GTP.

G-Protein Types

G-proteins are divided into three classes: Gs, Gi/o, and Gq.

G-Protein Functions

  • Gs stimulates adenylyl cyclase, increasing cAMP levels.

  • Gi/o inhibits adenylyl cyclase, reducing cAMP levels.

  • Gq activates phospholipase C, leading to IP3 and DAG production.

Second Messengers

cAMP, IP3, DAG, calcium ions, and others depending on the pathway.

Downstream Signaling Pathways

Activation of kinases, phosphatases, ion channels, and more.

Diversity of GPCRs

  • >800 GPCRs in humans, regulating diverse physiological processes.

  • Organized into families based on sequence homology.

Tissue Distribution

GPCRs are present in virtually all cell types and tissues.

Drug Targets

Many drugs target GPCRs for therapeutic purposes.

Examples of GPCR Ligands

  • Adrenaline (β-adrenergic receptors)

  • Serotonin (5-HT receptors)

  • Acetylcholine (muscarinic receptors)

  • Histamine (histamine receptors)

Signal Termination

Ligand dissociates from the receptor, G-protein hydrolyzes GTP to GDP, and system returns to basal state.

Regulation of GPCRs

Desensitization, internalization, and recycling of receptors to control responsiveness.

Importance in Physiology and Medicine

Critical in regulating diverse processes: neurotransmission, hormone release, immune response, etc.
